name: iris-versicolor
country-or-region-of-origin: Central & Eastern Canada to North Central & Eastern U.S.A
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
flower-description: 1-several at the top of a naked stem, 6-parted with 3 outer, spreading or pendent "falls" and 3 inner, erect "standards", variously colored The large 4-inch flowers bloom in late springÂ to early summer with several (3-5) on a naked stalk of up to 30 inches.
leaf-description: Blue green sword-like leaves 2 feet long and 1 inch wide, entire margins, they stand upright or arch slightly.
poison-symptoms:
CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR, OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.  Nausea, salivation, vomiting, abdominal pain, lethargy, diarrhea, elevated temperature following ingestion; skin irritation upon contact with seeds, rootstock, or cell sap.
Highest concentration in rhizomes.
poison-toxic-principle: Pentacylic terpenoids (zeorin, missourin and missouriensin), Irisin, iridin, or irisine
